results.title: Space flight
results.brief_description: Made by a special “Plasti-Cine” technique, in this film the hero, Dan, passes an amusing set of tests for health fitness, then flies a space rocket to the planet Venus. After battling the demon Nicotine, Dan persuades the Venusians to destroy the groves of cigarette trees to abolish smoking.

results.title: [Release prints compilation]
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)

results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: interactive software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]

results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This work presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Burger Burger
results.creator_credit: Gavin Jun Jie Tan and Huang Shicong
results.brief_description: The story of a marooned explorer who meets some local wildlife, with a scary - but eventually serendipitous - outcome. This colourful, fast-paced short animation won Best Animation at the Singapore Short Film Awards 2011.

results.title: Big Game
results.creator_credit: Jarrod Hasenjager and The Animation School (Cape Town)
results.brief_description:
Bobo, a lonely monster, is set to spend another birthday alone, until a cunning monster hunter throws him a killer surprise party!
Animators: Sarah Scrimgeour, Aarin Lehmkuhl, Romy Latter, Miro Kolenic, Jarrod Hasenjager, Matthew Furnell.

results.title: The Lost Thing
results.creator_credit: Leo Baker, Shaun Tan, Sophie Byrne, Andrew Ruhemann and Passion Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, this Oscar Award winning animated short film of Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’, tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeonholes.

results.title: Freedom
results.creator_credit: Bob Gatherum, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: During his trip back to Normandy on the 65th anniversary of D-day, Bob Gatherum reflects on the lasting legacy of war. Travelling through Normandy, he was surprised and amazed at the appreciation shown by the local people whose freedom he and his fellow soldiers had helped protect.
